unnormalised: The Maths Dept. at IIT Delhi just dropped a bombshell: mandatory LaTeX usage for *all* assignments! Students are reportedly stockpiling chai and frantically googling "how to escape backslash hell." Apparently, someone showed Prof. Sharma a beautifully typeset equation using AMSmath, and now handwritten submissions are officially extinct.
normalised: The Mathematics Department at I-I-T Delhi just dropped a bombshell: mandatory L-A-T-E-X usage for asterisk all asterisk assignments! Students are reportedly stockpiling chai and frantically googling "how to escape backslash hell." Apparently, someone showed Professor Sharma a beautifully typeset equation using A-M-S math, and now handwritten submissions are officially extinct.

unnormalised: A 1st-year student, identified only as Rohan (roll no. 2024CS101), was overheard lamenting, "I barely understand the maths *itself*, now I have to learn a whole new language just to write it down?! My GPA is doomed!" Others are taking a more…creative approach. Rumours abound of students attempting to use AI to translate their scribbled notes into elegant LaTeX code. Good luck with *that*, guys. Let me know how \frac{d}{dx} AI goes...
normalised: A first year student, identified only as Rohan (roll number two thousand twenty four C-S one zero one), was overheard lamenting, "I barely understand the maths asterisk itself asterisk, now I have to learn a whole new language just to write it down?! My G-P-A is doomed!" Others are taking a more…creative approach. Rumours abound of students attempting to use A-I to translate their scribbled notes into elegant L-A-T-E-X code. Good luck with asterisk that asterisk, guys. Let me know how the derivative with respect to x of A-I goes...

unnormalised: The official announcement stated that the move is intended to "enhance clarity and prepare students for advanced research." Unofficially, sources say it's because Prof. Sharma got tired of deciphering their chicken scratch. Whatever the reason, the LaTeX revolution has begun. The burning question: Will the next batch of engineers be fluent in equations, or just really good at copy-pasting from Stack Overflow? Only time (and countless compile errors) will tell.
normalised: The official announcement stated that the move is intended to "enhance clarity and prepare students for advanced research." Unofficially, sources say it's because Professor Sharma got tired of deciphering their chicken scratch. Whatever the reason, the L-A-T-E-X revolution has begun. The burning question: Will the next batch of engineers be fluent in equations, or just really good at copy-pasting from Stack Overflow? Only time (and countless compile errors) will tell.

unnormalised: One particularly cheeky student reportedly submitted their first assignment entirely in Comic Sans. Their reasoning? "If we're judged by aesthetics, then EVERYTHING should be beautiful!" The professor's response? An assignment grade of -10 (negative ten!) and a strongly worded email on proper typesetting and document ethics. Ouch. Looks like someone's gonna be spending a lot of time in office hours.
normalised: One particularly cheeky student reportedly submitted their first assignment entirely in Comic Sans. Their reasoning? "If we're judged by aesthetics, then E-V-E-R-Y-T-H-I-N-G should be beautiful!" The professor's response? An assignment grade of negative ten (negative ten!) and a strongly worded email on proper typesetting and document ethics. Ouch. Looks like someone's gonna be spending a lot of time in office hours.

unnormalised: So, to all the budding mathematicians out there struggling with \sum and \int, remember: you're not alone. Embrace the backslash, master the curly braces, and pray that your equations compile correctly. And if all else fails, blame it on a cosmic ray flipping a bit in your processor. After all, maths is hard enough without the added pressure of looking good doing it. Remember folks LaTeX is not just about \begin{equation} and \end{equation}, it's about surviving the semester.
normalised: So, to all the budding mathematicians out there struggling with summation and integral, remember: you're not alone. Embrace the backslash, master the curly braces, and pray that your equations compile correctly. And if all else fails, blame it on a cosmic ray flipping a bit in your processor. After all, maths is hard enough without the added pressure of looking good doing it. Remember folks L-A-T-E-X is not just about begin equation and end equation, it's about surviving the semester.
